{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3503687,"name":"Noah Sookraj","username":"NoahZeNairwhal","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5daacb/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T01:45:26.736Z","cooked":"

What material are other teams using in their end effectors? Right now we have one that’s a bunch of metal plates and it’s heavy than we’d like… It looks like some teams were using plexiglass or something? Just curious if there’s a lighter material we can use that’ll also be sturdy enough.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-06T01:45:26.736Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":359,"readers_count":358,"score":146.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485392,"topic_slug":"end-effector-material","display_username":"Noah Sookraj","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60051,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3692 Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/end-effector-material/485392/1","custom_user_title":"3692 Lead Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3503699,"name":"ben gates","username":"banjogates","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/banjogates/{size}/251059_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T01:55:20.528Z","cooked":"

Teams are mostly going to be using polycarbonate, also called Lexan or Makrolon. What you don’t want to use is acrylic, which looks similar but is extremely brittle. Polycarb is a super durable plastic that can be machined somewhat easily and is way lighter than alum. Nowhere near as rigid, but is very very strong in impact.

1/4" polycarb can be bought in a lot of places and is good for certain applications

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-06T01:55:20.528Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":351,"readers_count":350,"score":215.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":485392,"topic_slug":"end-effector-material","display_username":"ben gates","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":9}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38980,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"breh"},"post_url":"/t/end-effector-material/485392/2","custom_user_title":"breh","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":9,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3503745,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T03:34:28.203Z","cooked":"

By the way, “plexiglas”–referred to by the OP–is acrylic. Most FRC teams use acrylic once, usually by accident, then seek it out and palm it off on another innocent team throw it out in as many pieces as they can make it into.

Polycarb? Useful everywhere.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-06T03:34:28.203Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":307,"readers_count":306,"score":146.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":485392,"topic_slug":"end-effector-material","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":38980,"username":"banjogates","name":"ben gates","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/banjogates/{size}/251059_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/end-effector-material/485392/3","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3503961,"name":"Stewart Riley","username":"Strategic","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/strategic/{size}/10157_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T14:27:45.824Z","cooked":"

They’re usually throwing it out in pieces because that’s how it ends up coming off the robot whether they wanted it to or not. The field reset folks will not thank you for using acrylic.

HDPE / UHMWPE is another lightweight plastic option that’s tough enough for end effectors. But it’s very soft and floppy, so your have to design around that.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-06T14:31:24.236Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":214,"readers_count":213,"score":62.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485392,"topic_slug":"end-effector-material","display_username":"Brendan Simons, 5406","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/end-effector-material/485392/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3503965,"name":"Dan","username":"theworkshope","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/theworkshope/{size}/194375_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T14:39:02.678Z","cooked":"

Standard warning/ reminder not to use most threadlocker compounds with polycarbonate. It’s a pretty fantastic material, but will spider crack and fail when exposed to acetone (found in most loctite).

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-06T14:39:02.678Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":193,"readers_count":192,"score":78.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":485392,"topic_slug":"end-effector-material","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53412,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/end-effector-material/485392/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3503968,"name":"billbo911","username":"billbo911","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billbo911/{size}/110890_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T14:49:20.126Z","cooked":"

There are compounds that will work as a thread locker on poly. Silicon adhesives like RTV, and even caulking and wood glue can work. Always verify an adhesive on a spare piece of poly that can be thrown out once the test is done.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-06T14:49:20.126Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":174,"readers_count":173,"score":49.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485392,"topic_slug":"end-effector-material","display_username":"billbo911","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53412,"username":"theworkshope","name":"Dan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/theworkshope/{size}/194375_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"KN6MPS, WRWZ842"},"post_url":"/t/end-effector-material/485392/7","custom_user_title":"KN6MPS, WRWZ842","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3503987,"name":"Chris Cross","username":"WayCoolSuperDude","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/waycoolsuperdude/{size}/171772_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T15:27:37.777Z","cooked":"

For us, the material we use depends a lot on where the effector is located. If completely inside the frame, we mostly go with aluminum, although polycarb is also used. If it will be outside the frame, we almost always go with polycarb. As others have mentioned, be wary of thread locker around poly.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-06T15:27:37.777Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":152,"readers_count":151,"score":30.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":485392,"topic_slug":"end-effector-material","display_username":"Chris Cross","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38318,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Neither cool nor super."},"post_url":"/t/end-effector-material/485392/8","custom_user_title":"Neither cool nor super.","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3503997,"name":"ben gates","username":"banjogates","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/banjogates/{size}/251059_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T15:47:13.409Z","cooked":"

3357 found this out the hard way in 2022 with our almost full polycarb shooter and intake

Loctite makes a polycarb-safe threadlocker, but it’s literally just cyanoacrylate dyed blue.

edit: I knew I had photos of it somewhere (from 2022)

Thanks y’all for the answers! I’m a programmer so this sort of stuff isn’t my area of expertise I’ll bring up using polycarb at the next meeting.

A couple of mentors on my team use the term “Plexiglass” to refer to any clear plastic sheeting, i.e. the polycarbonate we’re using for our end effector, even though Plexiglass is just a brand name for poly(methyl methacrylate)/acrylic. Kinda drives me crazy…
